Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: First, Ill list out all the events with their details to see patterns. Starting with event 1: Register patient in ER, 45M, private insurance. Then event 2: another Register patient in ER, 62F, public. Event 3: Register in Surgery, 28M, private. Hmm, so three different patients being registered at the start.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Then event 4: Initial triage in ER, 45M. Thats the same age and gender as event 1s patient. So maybe event 1 and 4 are the same case? Because theyre both ER patients with the same age and gender. Let me check the timestamps. Event 1 is at 08:05:13, event 4 is 08:10:50. Thats about 5 minutes later, which makes sense for triage after registration.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Event 5: Initial triage in ER, 62F. That matches event 2s patient (62F, ER, public insurance). So events 2 and 5 might be the same case. Event 6: Doctor consultation in Surgery, 28M. Thats the same as event 3s patient (28M, Surgery, private). So events 3 and 6 could be the same case.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Event 7: Xray imaging in Radiology, 45M. Again, same as event 1 and 4. So this is probably the same case as event 1. Event 8: Lab test requested in ER, 62F. Thats event 2 and 5s patient. So events 2,5,8 might be part of the same case. Event 9: Surgery preparation in Surgery, 28M. Matches event 3 and 6. So events 3,6,9 are same case. Event 10: Lab test completed in Lab, 62F. This is the same patient as event 8 (62F), so events 8 and 10 would be same case. Event 11: Doctor consultation in ER, 62F. So this is the same patient as events 2,5,8,10. Event 12: Doctor consultation in ER, 45M. Same as events 1,4,7. So case 1,4,7,12. Event 13: Surgery performed in Surgery, 28M. This is the patient from event 3,6,9. So events 3,6,9,13. Event 14: Prescription created in ER, 62F. Again, same as the 62F patient (events 2,5,8,10,11).

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Event 15: Patient discharged in ER, 45M. So this is the same as events 1,4,7,12. Discharged after some procedures. Event 16: Recovery room in Surgery, 28M. This is the 28M patient (events 3,6,9,13). So after surgery, theyre in recovery. Event 17: Patient discharged in ER, 62F. So this is the 62F patient (events 2,5,8,10,11,14) being discharged. Event 18: Patient discharged in Surgery, 28M. The 28M patient (events 3,6,9,13,16) being discharged.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Let me try to group them step by step. First, look for patients with same age and gender and department. Since each case is a patient, same age, gender, department, and activity sequence should link them. Lets make tables for each possible patient.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 1: 45M, ER, private insurance. Events: 1. Register patient (ER) 4. Initial triage (ER) - same age/gender 7. Xray (Radiology) - same age/gender 12. Doctor consultation (ER) - same 15. Discharged (ER) - same So events 1,4,7,12,15. Check timestamps: 1 at 08:05, 4 at 08:10, 7 at 08:15, 12 at 08:23, 15 at 08:30. The timing seems sequential. After triage, Xray, then doctor consultation, then discharge.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 2: 62F, ER, public insurance. Events: 2. Register patient (ER) 5. Initial triage (ER) 8. Lab test requested (ER) 10. Lab test completed (Lab) 11. Doctor consultation (ER) 14. Prescription created (ER) 17. Discharged (ER) Check the sequence: 2 (08:07), 5 (08:12), 8 (08:16), 10 (08:20), 11 (08:22), 14 (08:27), 17 (08:35). Looks like theyre in order.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 3: 28M, Surgery, private insurance. Events: 3. Register patient (Surgery) 6. Doctor consultation (Surgery) 9. Surgery preparation (Surgery) 13. Surgery performed (Surgery) 16. Recovery room (Surgery) 18. Discharged (Surgery) Timestamps: 3 (08:07), 6 (08:13), 9 (08:16), 13 (08:25), 16 (08:31), 18 (08:40). This seems to be a surgical patient who had surgery and then recovery. Wait, event 3 is Register patient in Surgery, which might be a preop registration. Then doctor consultation (event 6), surgery prep (event 9), surgery performed (13), recovery (16), discharge (18).

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Let me check if all events are covered. List of events: 118. Case 1: 1,4,7,12,15 Case 2: 2,5,8,10,11,14,17 Case 3: 3,6,9,13,16,18 Lets count: Case 1: 5 events. Case 2: 7 events. Case 3: 6 events. Total 18 events. Yes, that adds up. Check event 12: Doctor consultation in ER for 45M. So same as case 1. Event 15: Discharge for 45M. Correct. Event 17: Discharge for 62F. Yes. Event 18: Discharge for 28M. Correct. Another check: event 10 is lab completed for 62F. Then event 11 is doctor consultation in ER for 62F. Makes sense. Event 14 is prescription for 62F (antibiotics), which would be after diagnosis of minor infection. Event 11 says diagnosis=minor_infection. So the doctor consultation (11) leads to prescription (14). Yes, thats a logical sequence. For case 3: surgery preparation (event 9) followed by surgery (13), then recovery (16), then discharge (18). Makes sense. Also, the departments for each case: Case 1: ER (register, triage, xray, consultation, discharge) Case 2: ER (register, triage, lab tests, consultation, prescription, discharge) Case 3: Surgery (register, consultation, prep, surgery, recovery, discharge) The key is that the patients age and gender are consistent across events in the same case. Also, the departments might change (like case 2 goes to lab), but the patients attributes (age, gender) stay the same. Another angle: the activity types. For example, the surgery case has a surgery performed, so its a surgical patient. Let me check if theres any overlap. For example, event 12 is a doctor consultation in ER for 45M. The previous event for that patient would be event 7 (xray) at 08:15. Then event 12 is at 08:23. So after xray, they had a doctor consultation. Thats logical. Similarly, case 2: after lab test completed (event 10 at 08:20), then doctor consultation (11 at 08:22), then prescription (14 at 08:27), then discharge (17 at 08:35). Yes, that seems to fit.
